item.title: Handle useEffect on Mount with useRef
item.description: As the documentation of React states, Hooks “let you use state and other React features without writing a class.” The useState Hook is used to manage the state of a component. If you need to do some data fetching, the useEffect Hook is the one to use. It’s default behaviour for React to run the Effect Hooks after every render. This always includes the first render, too. There might be use cases, when one wants to fetch some data, but only after e.
